security_audit.summary: Static analyzer flagged markdown syntax as security patterns. All findings are false positives. The backticks (lines 19, 25) are markdown code formatting, not shell execution. The YAML frontmatter (---) was misinterpreted as cryptographic syntax. The hardcoded URL is a documented feature for fetching guidelines from GitHub. This is a read-only review skill with no command execution capability.

low_findings.title: Markdown Syntax Misidentified as Command Execution
low_findings.description: The static analyzer detected backtick syntax at SKILL.md:19 and SKILL.md:25. These are markdown code formatting markers (inline `code` and code blocks ```), not shell backtick execution. This is a documentation file, not executable code.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks in markdown are explicitly for code formatting. Line 19 shows output format description using backticks for inline code. Lines 25-27 show a markdown code block containing a URL. No shell execution occurs.

low_findings.title: YAML Frontmatter Misidentified as Cryptographic Algorithm
low_findings.description: The static analyzer flagged YAML frontmatter (---) at SKILL.md:2-3 and SKILL.md:33 as 'weak cryptographic algorithm'. This is false positive - YAML frontmatter is standard markdown metadata syntax, not encryption.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: The --- delimiters define YAML frontmatter for metadata. This is standard documentation format used in many static site generators. No cryptographic operations occur.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URL for Guidelines Fetching
low_findings.description: A hardcoded URL to GitHub raw content exists at SKILL.md:26. This is an intentional design choice for fetching the latest web interface guidelines. The URL points to a public GitHub repository maintained by Vercel Labs.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: The URL is a documented, read-only fetch endpoint for guidelines. It does not transmit sensitive data and is central to the skill's documented functionality.

content.user_title: Review UI against web design guidelines
content.value_statement: Developers often build interfaces without following established best practices, leading to accessibility issues and poor user experience. This skill fetches the latest web interface guidelines from Vercel and automatically reviews code against them, providing actionable feedback in a standard file:line format.
actual_capabilities: Fetch latest web interface guidelines from a remote source
Review specified files or file patterns against the guidelines
Identify deviations from established web design best practices
Output findings in a concise file:line format
limitations: Cannot modify code to fix issues - only identifies problems
Guidelines are fetched at runtime and may change
Cannot access files outside the specified pattern or user input
Relies on externally hosted guidelines content

use_cases.title: Frontend Code Review
use_cases.description: A frontend developer wants to audit their React or Vue components for accessibility and design compliance before shipping. They invoke the skill with their component files to get a checklist of issues to fix.

use_cases.title: Design System Audit
use_cases.description: A design systems engineer needs to ensure their component library follows established web interface patterns. They run the skill across the entire library to identify inconsistencies.

use_cases.title: Learning Best Practices
use_cases.description: A new developer wants to learn what makes good web interfaces. They use the skill on their own code to see specific examples of where their design choices deviate from guidelines.

output: src/components/Button.tsx:15: Touch target should be at least 44x44px

best_practices: Always review UI code against established guidelines before committing
Use the skill during code review to catch accessibility issues early
Combine with manual testing to verify findings in actual browsers
anti_patterns: Don't ignore findings without understanding why they are flagged
Don't assume the skill can automatically fix issues for you
Don't skip accessibility testing in favor of relying solely on this skill

faq.question: How often are the guidelines updated?
faq.answer: The skill fetches the latest guidelines from GitHub each time it runs, ensuring you always use the most current version.

faq.question: Can this skill fix the issues it finds?
faq.answer: No, the skill only identifies issues. You will need to manually apply the fixes based on the reported line numbers.

faq.question: What file types can it review?
faq.answer: Any text-based file containing UI code. The skill checks the content against the guidelines regardless of file extension.

faq.question: Does it work with any JavaScript framework?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill is framework-agnostic. It reviews the code content against general web interface principles.

faq.question: How reliable are the findings?
faq.answer: The skill applies automated rules from established guidelines. It catches common issues but should be supplemented with manual accessibility testing.

faq.question: Can I use this offline?
faq.answer: No, the skill requires network access to fetch the latest guidelines from GitHub before performing reviews.
